node.doctext:
CST review archive 16

This is a storage node for CST reviews. Contents are moved her from [CST_Chat].

This archive begins on 05/15/05, When it's full we'll move to [CST_Storage_17].

See also Quest Storage collabs [CST_Storage_1|1], [CST_Storage_2|2], [CST_Storage_3|3], [CST_Storage_4|4], [CST_Storage_5|5], [CST_Storage_6|6], [CST_Storage_7|7], [CST_Storage_8|8], [CST_Storage_9|9], [CST_Storage_10|10], [CST_Storage_11|11], [CST_Storage_12|12], [CST_Storage_13|13], [CST_Storage_14|14], [CST_Storage_15|15], [CST_Storage_16|16].

Batch Processed 05/15/05 by gom

If you need any help please feel free to message me or [Content_Salvage].

Writeup Title: [Cellar Door]
Author: [Erik Fish]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: No
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: No
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.2.8 (5.1 min) JohnnyGoodyear says I like this, [Cellar Door] because I like the quote, and I'm sure it would be easy for them to expand here and there and pass the % test if they need. I guess the question is, do they need to?
Hi there, Bad news I'm afraid. I like this writeup, but it doesn't appear to be compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy]. If you'd like to add more original content and repost I'd be glad to assist you with copyright compliance. If you don't have the time or inclination, it will be removed from the database in a week or so.
Hi again. Well, I can see that you've updated this towards copyright compliance. Unfortunately, the quote now appears to be about 35% original work and the fair use rule says no more than 33%. You need to add another couple of sentences to push it over the top. One of them can be, "This write up has been reviewed and is [CST Approved]." Please let me know when you have updated so I can finish the review.
Bad news, as I've mentioned to you several times, this writeup isn't compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy]. It has been removed from the database. If you'd like to add more original content and repost I'd be glad to assist you with copyright compliance.
Tc = 196, Tq = 70, %q= 60%

Writeup Title: Turn Undead
Author: [Sontra]
Reviewer: [Ouroboros] (/msg with any comments on this)
Public domain?: No, content available under [Open Gaming License].
Original Author's Permission received?: No, unecessary.
Quoted content less than 33%: n/a
Compliance Assessment: Non-compliant, see below.
Review Request & Notes: The [Open Gaming License] provides for the reprint of OGL-licensed content when the OGL is "affix"ed to that content. In the publishing of d20 material by second-party designers (booklet or PDFs) this has meant the OGL in small print somewhere. Further, there must be a clear identification of what material is released under OGL and what material is kept copyright. E2 fails on both counts. These two requirement would be easy to fulfill. As a content editor, I feel that this now becomes a question of what we want to have on E2, and I feel strongly that E2 is NOT the place for a completely hypertext-ized edition of the D&D3(.5)e rules, or any other OGL game system. Some other website should do that. 30 March 2005

Writeup Title: [plastic jesus]
Author: [koreykruse]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Yes
Original Author's Permission received?: No
Quoted content less than 33%: No
Compliance Assessment: No
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2005.05.05 at 12:23 2005.05.26 at 04:33koreykruse says for Copyright Compliant Lyrics and Poems, I suggest my writeups in my [funny valentine] and [plastic jesus].
Hi there, Bad news I'm afraid. This writeup may not be compliant with the [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material|E2 Copyright Policy]. The E2 policy is 250 words maximum on copyrighted lyrics, your Marrs quote is 286. I'm not sure who holds the copyright to the version of [plastic jesus]that you are quoting, but I assume that they are copyrighted. Let's discuss...
2005.6.3 (49.1 min) koreykruse says /msg GrouchyOldMan re: Plastic Jesus . The first printed version of the song is by Marrs and Marrs says that the song does not belong to him. The lyrics had an oral tradition that preceded Marrs (see Nov. 1964 Sing Out! magazine article "Plastic Jesus Investigated"). I don't believe it is possible to have a valid copyright for works that are not original. Maybe I can ascertain whether or not anyone collects royalties for the song? It is also kind of odd because some people credit Rush and Cromarty with the song and others Marrs.
/msg koreykruse Thanks for the backstory. Based on your comments, I'd call it Public Domain, until someone asserts otherwise. I'd call it [CST Approved] on that basis.
Tc = 669, Tq = 194, %q= 29%

Writeup Title:[The guy's guide to geek girls]
Author:[Mer]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?: See notes.
Quoted content less than 33%: No.
Compliance Assessment: See notes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: [E2 Nuke Request] submitted by [lmichaud] Tue May 31 2005 at 14:21:11

I would like to request the deletion of the node at:

http://www.everything2.com/index.pl?node_id=1190672

I'm going to try and hard link it here:

[http://www.everything2.com/index.pl?node_id=1190672]

I am the author of this piece. I was never contacted about it being reproduced on another web page, and my copyright notice on the piece specifically requests that it not be reproduced on the web.

Thank you.

Lisa Michaud

(You can recycle this account, too - I have no intention of using it again.)
Editors’ Notes:[momomom] here.

I've added formatting to this and am looking for the original URL. I /msged the author but have not heard back, will google the title next.

[The guy's guide to geek girls] is the node that all linked to.

[http://cs.wheatoncollege.edu/pathways/humor/GuideToGeekGirls.html] is the original as far as I can tell. It says not to duplicate on another web page so I'm nuking it.

[lometa] says:

Please note that Mer's [The guy's guide to geek girls] write-up was submitted Wed Oct 31 2001 and 2001 does match the original copyright disclaimer by Ms. Michaud.

This essay is copyrighted by Lisa Michaud, ©1996, 1999, 2001. It may be saved, downloaded, or distributed in email or paper form providing that the author's name and this notice remain attached to the essay and no profit is obtained from the distribution.

In all fairness to [Mer], Ms. Michaud should have stated that she has updated her website and is rescinding the original copyright statement that is included in the E2 write up.

The updated web site is the one noted above by [momomom] however the original URL is:
[http://www.8thday.com/personal_content/society/dating/GuideToGeekGirls.htm]

The cache by Google of Ms. Michaud's previous web site that cites [Mer]’s copyright notice and can be seen [http://tinyurl.com/exna9|here].

For fair use compliance the quote should be 33% or less of the total wordcount. If you'd like to add more original content to bring it into compliance, I'd be glad to assist you.
2005.5.7 (20 hr) [mcc] says The quoted portion of that node is literally printed on the cover of the album in question. It is no different from inserting an album cover into the node, were that possible on e2, and little different from a track listing.
/msg [mcc]I see your point, but most albums have a copyright notice clearly printed on them. The [www.thresholdhouse.com|Coil website] says, "its entire contents, text, data files and images are copyright and may not be reproduced, duplicated, copied, sold, resold, or otherwise exploited for any commercial purpose without our express written consent." Unless you've got a reason to believe that the album text isn't under copyright your writeup is going to have to be updated for compliance or removed.
